importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the Paris Climate Agreement was adopted, marking a turning point in global climate policy and setting a new trajectory for global warming.
The start of the period used to define 'comparable days' in the study, based on 1991–2020 climate data for baseline comparison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The future period during which the projected increase in superhot days (57 per year) is expected to accumulate, reflecting long-term climate change impacts.

keyTakeAways: The world is on track for an additional 57 superhot days annually by 2100 due to climate change, a significant but reduced increase from the worst-case scenario of 114 days under pre-Paris warming.
The Paris Climate Agreement has reduced projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, halving the number of additional superhot days compared to the pre-2015 trajectory.
Since 2015, the world has already experienced an average of 11 additional superhot days.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face disproportionate increases in dangerous heat, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra superhot days annually.
These 10 most affected nations collectively emit only 1% of global greenhouse gases, highlighting a major climate injustice.

The top carbon-emitting countries — the United States, China, and India — are responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions yet face only 23–30 extra superhot days, indicating a severe disconnect between emissions and climate impacts.
The study reveals that climate change impacts are deeply unfair, exacerbating global inequalities and potentially fueling geopolitical instability.
Experts emphasize that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by the rising frequency of dangerous heat, with thousands already dying in heatwaves annually.

namedEntities.name: World Weather Attribution
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that studies climate-related extreme events and their attribution to climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The study that calculates the increase in superhot days due to climate change is conducted by this entity, establishing its authority in climate attribution science.

namedEntities.name: Climate Central
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based non-profit climate research organization focused on climate data and extreme weather analysis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central collaborated with World Weather Attribution in producing the study, contributing to the credibility and scope of the findings.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement changed the trajectory of global warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, directly influencing the number of projected superhot days.

namedEntities.name: Johan Rockstrom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Potsdam Climate Institute, a leading figure in climate science and policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His commentary emphasizes that even with reduced warming, the future climate remains disastrous for billions of people, reinforcing the urgency of climate action.

namedEntities.name: Friederike Otto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Co-author of the study and climate scientist at Imperial College London.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides a key estimate on human impact, stating that tens of thousands or millions will be affected by the rising heat, emphasizing the scale of harm.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Weaver
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Climate scientist at the University of Victoria, not part of the research team.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He highlights the geopolitical implications of climate injustice, noting that unequal heat exposure could deepen global divisions.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Panama is among the top 10 countries projected to gain the most superhot days (149 per year), illustrating disproportionate climate vulnerability.

namedEntities.name: Solomon Islands
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, ocean-dependent nation in Oceania.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the nations expected to face the largest increase in dangerous heat days, highlighting climate injustice in vulnerable small states.

namedEntities.name: Samoa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, island nation in Oceania.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A top 10 country projected to experience a massive spike in superhot days, showing how low-emitting nations suffer most from climate change.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the world's largest carbon emitters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Despite being responsible for a large share of emissions, it is projected to see only a small increase in superhot days, showing a disconnect between emissions and exposure.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the world's largest carbon emitters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China emits a large portion of global CO₂ but faces only a minimal increase in superhot days, illustrating climate inequity.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the world's largest carbon emitters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India contributes significantly to global emissions but is projected to experience only 23–30 extra superhot days, emphasizing the unequal burden of climate change.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that climate change will add 57 superhot days annually by 2100 under the current warming trajectory of 2.6°C, a significant reduction from the 114-day increase projected under a pre-Paris warming path of 4°C. Although the Paris Agreement has helped avert the worst-case scenario, the world still faces a dangerous and growing number of extreme heat days. The study reveals a stark global inequality in climate impacts, with small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa facing massive spikes in heat—up to 149 extra days per year—despite emitting just 1% of global greenhouse gases. In contrast, the top polluters like the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts warn that this imbalance could deepen global disparities and fuel geopolitical instability, and that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by the increasing frequency of deadly heatwaves.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
